executive_summary: The Cable Shopping Networks industry, which retails a variety of consumer products through TV broadcasts, has contracted over the five years to 2022 due to shifting consumer shopping habits and a steep economic decline in 2020 as a result of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic. Industry operators have also experienced rising competition from online retailers, as consumers are increasingly shopping online, with e-commerce sales rising strongly over the past five years. As a result, industry revenue has fallen an annualized 6.7% to $5.3 billion over the five years to 2022, including a decline of 6.2% in 2022 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Over the five years to 2022, the industry has gradually contracted due to shifting consumer preferences and an economic downturn in 2020 due to the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic. Despite rising disposable income and consumer spending over the period, revenue has declined as it is not able to compete with the increased demand from e-commerce.

Profit can vary significantly from company to company, and are mostly dependent on the overall scale of the business. Typically, larger operators gain high profit because they can negotiate more favorable rates with product manufacturers.

Given its steady decline in recent years, the industry has gradually downsized operations to focus resources on e-commerce, which is not included in this industry. Thus, industry employment has decreased at an annualized rate of 2.6% to 16,502 people over the five years to 2022.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Given steadily expanding online competition, cable shopping networks will likely further diversify operations over the next five years. In recent years, shopping networks have established online retailing businesses, all of which experienced rapid growth.

While jewelry and other luxury product segments are anticipated to experience an uptick in demand, the industry is still expected to structurally consolidate due to competition from e-commerce sites. The number of establishments is anticipated to fall an annualized 0.3% to 61 locations over the five years to 2027.

While most major players are not anticipated to significantly expand their shopping network businesses, industry operators are expected to nonetheless introduce further initiatives to promote sales. Cable shopping networks can potentially boost business by developing more interactive and original programming.

industry_definition: This industry includes companies that use TV programs on subscription or fee-basis cable channels to generate clients and display merchandise. The industry excludes companies that are primarily engaged in generating sales through door-to-door marketing, direct-mail advertising, catalog sales, brick-and-mortar retail or e-commerce.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand is influenced by economic factors such as disposable income and consumer confidence, as unemployment and economic downturns reduce spending on discretionary items marketed on cable shopping networks.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Competition from E-commerce and Online Entertainment
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The rise of e-commerce and online entertainment options like movies and shows has reduced subscriptions for cable TV and limited the potential customer base for cable shopping networks.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The Cable Shopping Networks industry services domestic consumers and does not participate in international trade, although some major players operate in foreign markets.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region has the highest percentage of both business establishments (around 30%) and population (around 25%).
The West region has the second-highest percentage of business establishments (around 20%) and population (around 22%).
The Southeast region has a relatively high percentage of population (around 20%) but a lower percentage of business establishments (around 15%).
The New England region has a moderate percentage of both business establishments (around 10%) and population (around 8%).
The Great Lakes region has a moderate percentage of both business establishments (around 10%) and population (around 12%).
The Southwest region has a slightly higher percentage of business establishments (around 10%) compared to its population (around 8%).
The Plains region has the lowest percentage of both business establishments (around 5%) and population (around 5%).
The Rocky M (likely Rocky Mountains) region has the lowest percentage of both business establishments (around 5%) and population (around 2%).

regulations_points.regulation_description: Federal regulations for cable providers are undertaken by the US Federal Communications Commission (FCC). The FCC monitors technological compliance, particularly in the areas of general availability of service to households and noninterference with other telecommunications signals.
The FCC's social responsibility charter requires operators to report on equal opportunity policies, measures and outcomes.

regulations_points.regulation_title: State sales tax laws for online sales
regulations_points.regulation_description: In December 2013, the US Supreme Court rejected Amazon.com Inc. and Overstock.com's attempt to appeal a New York law requiring e-commerce companies to collect sales taxes from consumers regardless of where their facilities are located.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Local rate regulation for basic cable services
regulations_points.regulation_description: Local franchising authorities are responsible for regulating the basic-service tier. These authorities establish a benchmark rate based on the number of subscribers, channels and several other factors.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the decline stage of its life cycle.
The industry experiences high revenue volatility.
The industry has high capital intensity requirements.
The industry receives low and steady levels of assistance.
The industry faces high and increasing levels of competition.

basis_points.basis_description: All shopping networks compete on the basis of brand recognition, value and quality of products and accessibility.
Cable shopping networks compete with other providers of leisure and entertainment services and different forms of retail.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The top two companies are expected to account for 90.0% of revenue in 2022.
The growing dominance of e-commerce has steadily lured customers away from cable shopping networks.
Industry operators must increasingly compete with other TV entertainment providers.
Qurate Retail Group acquired the Home Shopping Network Inc. in 2017, significantly increasing its market share.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Transportation, insurance, interest and other expenses
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Operators contend with high transportation, insurance, interest and other expenses. For example, products must be delivered to consumers, which contributes to a consistently high level of transportation expenses.
Research and development are expected to account for the majority of other costs for the industry.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: High capital expenditure relative to wages
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: In 2022, for every dollar spent on wages, the average industry operator will spend $0.46 on capital investments. The industry is reliant on expensive pieces of equipment and the most up to date technology in order to perform their services.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Dependent on agreements with pay TV operators
volatility_points.volatility_description: In the long term, Cable Shopping Networks industry revenue depends on operators' relationship with pay TV operators, which are detailed through agreements.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Dependent on consumer spending and disposable income
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry also is dependent on consumer spending habits and disposable income, as increases in both of these factors typically boost industry revenue.
Over the past five years, the industry experienced a high level of revenue volatility. Notably, industry revenue increased as much as 12.5% in 2018 and decreased as much as 19.5% in 2021.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Shift to online shopping and e-commerce
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Cable Shopping Networks industry has endured high pressure from the growth of online shopping over the past five years. As online-based players generally operate at lower overhead costs, they can compete vigorously on price.

Technological advancements have enabled shoppers to search and browse for products on various platforms, including web browsers and mobile applications. The increasing use of handheld devices has also supported this growth.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Shift from analog to digital broadcasting
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many operators have switched from analog to digital networks following the large investment by cable providers to expand high-speed data and video-on-demand services.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Edge QAMs enabling more efficient data transmission
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Edge QAMs, unlike their standard counterpart, can carry multiple types of data streams, which can lower the operating costs of cable networks and cable providers.

FAQs.question: How have changes in individual consumer electronic use changed your operations?
FAQs.answer: The shift to e-commerce has severely threatened the industry. Consumers are showing an increasing preference for shopping online, which has taken away from the industry.

FAQs.question: Does technology change for your customers significantly affect your company?
FAQs.answer: Besides the fact that consumers are increasingly shopping online, cable TV subscriptions are decreasing. This shrinks the potential customer base for industry companies. This trend is expected to continue over the next five years.

FAQs.question: Does the existence of large technology companies affect your operational costs?
FAQs.answer: The existence of large technology companies does not necessarily affect operational costs. It does, however, affect industry performance as many tech companies' products directly compete with TV, the industry's primary delivery method.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to rising wages in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Wages are not a significant expense to industry companies. Given the retail nature of the industry, companies spend the most money on the purchase of goods for resale.

FAQs.question: Has your company prepared adequately to address the increased security risks posed by digital data storage?
FAQs.answer: Companies must ensure that the financial and personal information of customers is safe and secure. The largest companies have tens of millions of customers and risk reputation damage should there be a breach.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to keep current with changing digital interfaces?
FAQs.answer: Even as the industry is in the decline phase of its life cycle, companies within the industry are not necessarily dying out so quickly. QVC and HSN, the two largest networks, run very successful e-commerce websites, which has helped keep both companies afloat.

FAQs.question: Are you or your competitors facing scrutiny from antitrust litigation?
FAQs.answer: Though the industry is in decline, the two largest companies (QVC and HSN) now operate under one company, Qurate Retail Group. This new company makes about three-quarters of the industry.

FAQs.question: Have any recent regulatory changes significantly affected your operations?
FAQs.answer: Regulation does not play a large role in this industry. The biggest threat comes from e-commerce and the declining TV viewership.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Companies sell directly to consumers, who may have the option of paying over time or paying in total at the time of sale.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Given the size of QVC and HSN, both combining to about three-quarters of the industry, average profit margins are generally a reflection of the performance of these two companies.

FAQs.question: Have you used advertising to attract more clients? Have you allocated an appropriate proportion of your revenue to promotion?
FAQs.answer: Cable shopping networks that aggressively market their programming and product selection are more likely to attract customers.

FAQs.question: How hard is it to promote your company by word-of-mouth recommendations? Can you improve your company to receive better word-of-mouth?
FAQs.answer: Cable shopping networks must retain customers in addition to gaining new ones to compete in this industry.

FAQs.question: What measures do you have in place to reduce operational costs? Are you considering any new cost-saving measures?
FAQs.answer: Cable shopping networks that are able to negotiate down fixed costs such as distribution agreement fees with cable and satellite providers will remain profitable.

FAQs.question: To what degree does your demographic rely on the internet for similar products? Do you adjust your prices to compete with online options?
FAQs.answer: E-commerce sales measure product sales conducted online, which poses considerable competition to cable shopping networks. E-commerce sales serve as a substitute service to cable shopping networks. As a result, when e-commerce sales increase, demand for cable shopping networks suffers.

FAQs.question: How is your establishment affected when consumer confidence is low? How do you appeal to consumers during these times?
FAQs.answer: High levels of consumer confidence strengthen revenue growth for industry operators.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? How do you prepare for such changes in demand?
FAQs.answer: When consumers have more discretionary income, demand for these products typically increases, making disposable income a major driver of demand for cable shopping networks.
